title: Bernie Sanders Says Bill Clinton Owes Americans an Apology
content:
Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders is joined by musician and activist Harry Belafonte at the Apollo Theater in Harlem , N.Y .
NEW YORK – Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders condemned parts of Bill Clinton ’ s record on Saturday and said the former president owed Americans an apology over a tense exchange with Black Lives Matter protesters at a campaign event earlier this week .
Appearing at a forum centering on race at the Apollo Theater in Harlem , Mr. Sanders made clear he has sharp differences with Mr. Clinton ’ s handling of crime and poverty during his two-term presidency . He also rebuked Mr. Clinton for defending his wife ’ s use of the phrase “ super predator ” in the 1990s to describe perpetrators of violent crime .
“ The president owes the American people an apology for trying to defend what is indefensible , ” Mr. Sanders said .
When someone in the audience at the Apollo shouted that the “ super predator ” reference was code for “ black people , ” the Vermont senator said : “ That ’ s exactly right . ”
Mr. Sanders and Hillary Clinton are battling to win the New York primary on April 19 . Having done poorly with minority voters in earlier contests , Mr. Sanders has been trying to forge stronger ties to the African-American community as the campaign moves to diverse states like New York .
The event at the Apollo was one such effort , with Mr. Sanders sharing a stage with African-American supporters including entertainer Harry Belafonte and Erica Garner , daughter of Eric Garner , who died two years ago in a struggle with police who put him in a choke hold .
Asked his thoughts on Mrs. Clinton , Mr. Belafonte , who is also a civil-rights activist , said : “ Hillary who ? We ’ ve been there and done that . ”
The first question Mr. Sanders got from the moderator involved Mr. Clinton ’ s extended back-and-forth with a pair of protesters in Philadelphia on Thursday .
In that exchange , Mr. Clinton sought to explain his wife ’ s use of the term “ super predator. ” He talked about gang leaders who were getting teenagers “ hopped up on crack ” and sending them out to kill other African-Americans .
“ Maybe you thought they were good citizens ; she didn ’ t , ” Mr. Clinton told the protesters .
In the same event he also defended a bill he signed as president in 1996 overhauling the welfare system by imposing limitations on federal assistance and enacting new work requirements .
When protesters said the welfare law increased poverty , Mr. Clinton said , “ Then why did we have the largest drop in African-American poverty in history when I was president ? ” He blamed Republicans for subsequently undercutting the program by yanking money intended to cushion the law ’ s impact .
Mr. Sanders was unsparing in his criticism of the welfare legislation , casting it as a cynical ploy to win votes .
“ Do you all remember that ? ” he asked the audience . “ The premise , which was a right-wing Republican premise , was that the problem was all these people were really living high off the hog . ”
A consequence of the new law was that “ extreme poverty … went up , '' Mr. Sanders said .
Mr. Clinton signed the law as he was campaigning for re-election in 1996 .
“ Here are people who are helpless , who are barely making it economically , ” Mr. Sanders said . “ To go after them to win votes and cut the benefits of children and moms is unacceptable . ”
Mr. Clinton ’ s office did n't immediately respond to a request for comment . A day after his clash with the protesters , Mr. Clinton voiced regrets over the episode . He said he was n't especially “ effective ” in dealing with the criticism .
